Title: How to prove that homomorphism from field to ring is injective or zero?
Content: Possible Duplicate: Abstract Algebra ring homomorphism $f:K\rightarrow R$ is a homomorphism from field to ring. To prove is that it is injective or zero.
AcceptedAnswer: A ring homomorphism $f: R \to R'$ is injective if and only if its kernel is $\{0\}$ . Also, the kernel of a ring homomorphism is an ideal. Now let $f: K \to R$ be a ring homomorphism from a field into a ring. The only ideals in a field $K$ are $\{0\}$ and $K$ itself. Hence $f$ can either have kernel $\{0\}$ or $K$ itself. In the former case, $f$ is injective, in the latter case it is the zero map. Hope this helps.
